column4: IS anyone here familiar with Ubuntu BIND9 and Windows systems?
with bind9 and with ubuntu, and with windows systems, but not together. What problem do you have?

I'm running BIND9 on my Ubuntu 6.06.1LTS station. I've got other Ubuntu boxes taht use it & DNS works fine. However, if I have any Windows box try to query it I get either time outs or non existant domains.
what command are you using on windows to query? Have you doublechecked the windows machines query your dns servers?
I assume you are using   dig  in ubuntu to test dns?
I do: nslookup "machine name" ex: nslookup herbie.sjc-net.com
their primary DNS is set to my DNS server
Even I do not herbie.sjc-net.com , actually not even sjc-net.com
whois claims the domain does not exist.

if I perform the look up from any Ubuntu/Linux box I get what I expect. But if I try it from Windows, it fails. The only thing I can think of is I only have a forward zone. Do I need the reverse as well?
you were trying some local fake domain setup?
lynoure: yes. its all local. its an internal network only. its not exposed to the outside world.
I'd recommend not using real toplevels for that.
This would not happen to be for schoolwork or something? :)
lynoure: no. experimenting with Ubuntu in server roles here at work.
my wild guess would be that the windows machines are checking with toplevel name servers about  sjc-net.com and then give up as they get "does not exist" for it, but I do not know how to change it.
lynoure: see thats what i cant get... they are part of sjc-net.com, and the DNS server is set to be my server.
I told you there does not seem to be sjc-net.com, or at least whois says so, so if .com is asked about it, those name servers will also say it does not exist
not a problem you,d have with a real domain
its a private domain. so why wouldnt the first DNS server which holds the sjc-net.com domain return it?
I can poke around a bit if you tell me what the nameserver is
You cant get to it. Its not exposed.
ok, then I think I'll leave you to it, it just being a trial anyway
